Derek James wrote:

>Thanks for the answers and input so far...I'll comment on some of them
>a bit more later.
>
>But another quick question:
>
>One of the reasons for penalizing oscillations in the double pole
>balancing task is to make it more difficult, right?  Since the
>solution does not involve the network having to compute the velocities
>itself.
>  
>
That is the explanation given by Graua in "A comparison between cellular 
encoding and direct encoding for genetic neural neytworks":

http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/cache/papers/cs/13526/http:zSzzSzearth.cs.ttu.eduzSz~pyeattzSzpaperszSzgp96.pdf/gruau96comparison.pdf

Check the last paragraph on page 1.

I suspect though that fast movement in such a simulation may allow the 
simulation to cheat the laws of physics somewhat because of the large 
amount of movement between timesteps, and this /may/ make a solution 
easier. This is just speculation but certainly the accuracy of the 
simulation is less if the cart and poles are moving at higher speeds.

>But if it were a real-world system we wouldn't care what the network
>did or didn't have to compute, right?  If anything, if it could solve
>the problem more effectively without extra computation, that's a good
>thing.
>  
>
Yes, I'd go along with that.

>One of the real-world constraints we *do* care about is the amount of
>energy the system uses.  In Risto Miikkulainen's Evolving Neural
>Networks workshop at GECCO this year he showed one of the resulting 2d
>pole balancing solutions that solve the problem, but would have
>consumed enormous amounts of energy if it were actually implemented in
>a real-world controller.
>  
>
>So wouldn't it make more sense to penalize the amount of movement of
>the cart?  Wouldn't this be not only a simpler penalty to implement,
>but be functionally very close to what you want to achieve?
>  
>
This is effectively what the anti-wiigle function is doing, albeit in an 
inprecise way. It just totals the absolute value of the cart and pole 1 
velocities and positions, which are all centered around 0 and tries to 
minimise them. You could try just minimizing the cart velocity, or some 
other combination of cart and pole variables. An alternative would be to 
limit the maximum force that the network can apply, but that /may/ leave 
your networks stranded in local optima. On the other hand the current 
anti-wiggle approach often tends to find high energy wiggling solutions 
and then must try and find its way across the search space to an 
no-wiggling solution - which could be just as difficult.

Perhaps some experimentation is required to settle this matter!

Colin.
